```{r}
#| label: setup

knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  fig.align = "center",
  out.width = "100%",
  dpi = 300,
  fig.align = "center"
)

if (!require("renv")) install.packages("renv")
library(renv)
renv::restore(prompt = FALSE)

if (!require("countdown")) install.packages("countdown")
library(countdown)

if (!require("here")) install.packages("here")
library(here)

# Load colors from JSON
if (!require("jsonlite")) install.packages("jsonlite")
library(jsonlite)

if(!require("qrcode")) install.packages("qrcode")
library(qrcode)

if(!require("cropcircles")) install.packages("cropcircles")
library(cropcircles)

include_local_figure <- function(data_source) {
  knitr::include_graphics(
    path = here::here(
      "Materials",
      data_source
    ),
    error = TRUE
  )
}
```

# [Ecosystem Properties]{.r-fit-text} {.text-center .text-color-white .bg-indigo .text-margin-top} 

## Ecosystem properties

<br>

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%" .incremental} 
- [Ecosystem properties]{.text-background-indigo} are used to describe the [past vegetation]{.text-background-wisteria} and its [dynamics]{.text-background-blue}
- use various [community ecology]{.text-background-indigo} metrics to describe the current [status]{.text-background-wisteria} of each community (i.e. spatio-temporal sample)
- Reflect the [multidimensional]{.text-background-indigo} aspects of [biodiversity]{.text-background-blue}
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

<br>
<br>

```{r}
#| label: icon-ecosystem-1
include_local_figure("Preprint/Icons/icon_ecosystem.png")
```
:::
::::

## Ecosystem properties

### Variables:

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%" .incremental} 
- Diversity (Hill numbers)
- Evenness 
- Taxonomic turnover (DCCA)
- Rate of vegetation change (Roc)
- Temporal density of biodiversity change (change points)
:::

::: {.column width="30%" .fragment}

## Predictor importance - example record
:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .incremental}

- To estimate relative importance of [human]{.text-background-gold}/[climate]{.text-background-green} for variability in past ecosystem properties
- [Redundancy analysis]{.text-background-blue} (RDA with standardised response variables) 
- hierarchical variation partitioning ([HVARPART]{.text-background-indigo}) 
   + adjusted r2
   + [predictor importance ratio]{.text-background-black} = selected predictor importance / (total predictor importance)

:::

## Temporal analyses - methods

<br>

::: {.incremental}
- for each continent, make a slice for each 500 years
- calculate the [predictor importance]{.text-background-indigo} for each slice
- use (separately) both [human events]{.text-background-black} and [human presence]{.text-background-gold} (SPD) as a predictor
- use [climate]{.text-background-green} for all analyses
:::

## Can [human]{.text-background-gold}/[climate]{.text-background-green} better explain the changes in [interrelationships]{.text-background-blue} of past ecosystem properties?

<br>

### What if ...

<br>

::: {.incremental}
- [human]{.text-background-gold} have not altered the [Ecosystem Properties]{.text-background-indigo} themselves?
- but rather [interrelationships]{.text-background-wisteria} (correlation structures) of the [Ecosystem Properties]{.text-background-indigo}?
:::

## Interrelationships of Ecosystem Properties - methods

<br>

::: {.incremental}
- for each 500 yr time slice within each Climate zone in each continent ...
- make [principal component analysis]{.text-background-indigo} (PCA with standardisation of the metrics)
- between time slices, make [Procrustes sum-of-squares]{.text-background-wisteria} analysis to compare the changes in the interrelationships
- make symmetric scaling (m2) to create distance matrices
- [HVARPART]{.text-background-blue} using m2-distances between time slices
:::

# [Summary]{.r-fit-text} {.bg-indigo .text-center .text-color-white .text-margin-top}

## Main findings {.bg-black .text-color-white auto-animate="true"}

<br>

::: {.text-center}
We have summaried over [75,000 vegetation assemblages]{.text-background-indigo} in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by [9 ecosystem properties]{.text-background-wisteria}. We have also included over [150,000 radiocarbon dates]{.text-background-gold} derived from archaeological data and [4 past climate variables]{.text-background-green}.
:::

## Main findings {.bg-black .text-color-white auto-animate="true"}

::: {.text-center .text-color-gray}
We have summaried over 75,000 vegetation assemblages in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by 9 ecosystem properties. We have also included over 150,000 radiocarbon dates derived from archaeological data and 4 past climate variables.
:::

<br>

::: {.text-center}
This is the first study to [quantitatively]{.text-background-indigo} estimate the relative importance of [human]{.text-background-gold} and [climate]{.text-background-green} effects on vegetation properties globaly and during the early-to-mid [Holocene]{.text-background-wisteria}.
:::


## Main findings {.bg-black .text-color-white auto-animate="true"}

::: {.text-center .text-color-gray}
We have summaried over 75,000 vegetation assemblages in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by 9 ecosystem properties. We have also included over 150,000 radiocarbon dates derived from archaeological data and 4 past climate variables.
:::

::: {.text-center .text-color-gray} 
This is the first study to quantitatively estimate the relative importance of human and climate effects on vegetation properties globaly and during the early-to-mid Holocene.
:::

<br>

::: {.text-center}
[Localy]{.text-background-indigo}, [humans]{.text-background-gold .bold} had [severe impact]{.text-color-highlight-tertiary} on vegetation change during the early-to-mid [Holocene]{.text-background-wisteria}.
:::

## Main findings {.bg-black .text-color-white auto-animate="true"}

::: {.text-center .text-color-gray}
We have summaried over 75,000 vegetation assemblages in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by 9 ecosystem properties. We have also included over 150,000 radiocarbon dates derived from archaeological data and 4 past climate variables.
:::

::: {.text-center .text-color-gray} 
This is the first study to quantitatively estimate the relative importance of human and climate effects on vegetation properties globaly and during the early-to-mid Holocene.
:::

::: {.text-center .text-color-gray}
Localy, humans had severe impact on vegetation change during the early-to-mid Holocene.
:::

<br>

::: {.text-center}
[At a larger scale]{.text-background-indigo}, [climate]{.text-background-green .bold} was the [main driver]{.text-color-highlight-tertiary} of vegetation change during the early-to-mid [Holocene]{.text-background-wisteria}.
:::
